name: NPR
text:
This year's pilgrimage to the Basilica of Our Lady of Guadalupe was canceled, so one church put a portrait of Our Lady on a truck.

"This year instead of the people going on pilgrimage to the mother, it is the mother who goes on pilgrimage to her people."
https://t.co/77vpU3cv7C

name: NPR
text: Vaccines are en route. An executive with UPS told NPR about the complicated and challenging journey. https://t.co/gbwWOajg0i

text:

name: NPR
text:
Using only the letters in RIDE ON ‚Äî repeating them as often as necessary ‚Äî you can spell:

1) the one-word proper name of a famous fictional animal, and 

2) a word for what kind of animal it is. 

What's the name of the animal, and what's the word?
https://t.co/qNlFfNEkyA

name: NPR
text:
Go ahead and take that nap.

 "A 20 minute nap can make up for one hour of lost sleep," a sleep researcher says. (From our archive) https://t.co/j2aGBuExPI

name: NPR
text:
Say yes to that second s'more and dressing like an onion when socializing outdoors. 

The art of weathering winter isn't just about nailing the gear. It's also about mindset. 

In Norway, there's a long tradition called friluftsliv: "free, outdoor life." https://t.co/Ol6vi0gAiw

name: NPR
text:
The world's 5 centibillionaires aren't alone in getting richer as many people struggle to make ends meet. 

The 651 U.S. billionaires have seen their collective wealth rise by over $1 trillion roughly since the pandemic began, a report finds.

Read more: https://t.co/pkHVV4mtHx https://t.co/QR83LsNlsC

text:

Here's what we know so far, including how soon to expect your first dose: https://t.co/MXeF2bemak

name: NPR
text:
When this university chose to hold its graduation ceremonies in person, it decided to test every attendee, who'd remain socially distant and masked.

But some weren't able to get a test until the afternoon before.

That's where the private jet comes in.
 https://t.co/LE4pDSJYf0

name: NPR
text:

@LouderThanARiot reveals the story of his murder that hasn‚Äôt been told: how law enforcement lied about using the rapper‚Äôs past to sideline someone else‚Äôs future.https://t.co/5jY42rmayh

name: NPR
text:
Does the term POC obscure racial differences ‚Äî or build a bigger coalition? Or both?

Shereen and @NPRCodeSwitch explore whether "POC" has outlived its usefulness.

Watch the full: https://t.co/jwpLx8J1QZ https://t.co/TuDCebBP6S

name: NPR
text:
Michigan Gov. Gretchen Whitmer said the state's Electoral College voters will cast their votes within a closed capitol building, citing a "security issue."

Over the weekend, the building was advised to be closed due to "credible threats of violence."
https://t.co/6mErxj0FrX

text:

text:

text:
Every year, the Library of Congress adds 25 movies to the National Film Registry to be preserved for posterity. This year's list includes a record number of female directors and directors of color.

See the full list here:

text: Dr. Chizoba Barbara Wonodi of Johns Hopkins University explains why a strategy to vaccinate everyone may not be the best approach to fighting the virus in lower-income countries such as Nigeria. https://t.co/YRk99kCnij

name: NPR
text:
More than 300,000 people have died from COVID-19 in the U.S.

It is the latest sign of a generational tragedy, one still unfolding in every corner of the country that leaves in its wake an expanse of grief that cannot be captured in a string of statistics. https://t.co/EbJNDj3QrZ

text:

name: NPR
text:
The first people in the U.S. are receiving the COVID-19 vaccine today. 

"I feel like healing is coming," New York nurse Sandra Lindsay said after receiving her shot. "I hope this marks the beginning to the end of a very painful time in our history."
